info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued September 30 at 11:51AM EDT until September 30 at 4:00PM EDT by NWS Charleston
info.description: The National Weather Service in Charleston has extended the * Flash Flood Warning for... Berkeley County in southeastern South Carolina... Charleston County in southeastern South Carolina... * Until 400 PM EDT. * At 1142 AM EDT, Charleston Police reported that the Crosstown was closed due to flooding. In addition, numerous streets across Downtown Charleston were closed due to flood waters. This flooding was a result of 3 to 5 inches of rainfall that has fallen so far today. A band of heavy rainfall may continue to produce torrential rainfall rates over Charleston and the surrounding areas well into this afternoon. This band may produce an additional 2 to 3 inches of rain. Little to no storm water drainage will occur until the tide waters fall later this afternoon, likely producing flash flooding across the city of Charleston. In addition, water levels on Church Creek near West Ashley continue to steadily rise, on this pace the creek could exceed flood stage later this afternoon. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Rain bands with Hurricane Ian. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... North Charleston, Mount Pleasant, Downtown Charleston, James Island, West Ashley, Daniel Island, I-26/I-526 Interchange, Fort Sumter, Johns Island, Isle Of Palms, Folly Beach, Sullivan`s Island, Charles Towne Landing, Charleston Naval Complex, Maybank Bridge, James Island County Park, Fort Johnson, Don Holt Bridge and Sullivans Island. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. High tide will inhibit runoff of heavy rain, flooding areas of poor drainage in Downtown Charleston. Areas most prone to flooding include the Market, Crosstown, East Bay Street and Morrison Drive. Flooding is likely in low-lying coastal areas where high tide will inhibit runoff of heavy rain.
